channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Is Confronting New U.S. Hostility. But Is It Ready for the Fight?
item.media:description: China’s president, Xi Jinping, arriving at the opening ceremony of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing this month.
item.description: As the acrimony intensifies, Beijing’s immediate worry is how the Chinese public will handle the trade war and what impact it might have on domestic stability.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: French Turn on Macron, as They Grow Impatient for Results
item.media:description: The weekly farmer’s market in Montmorillon, in central-western France. From villages to the district’s ancient towns, the judgment of President Emmanuel Macron is largely negative.
item.media:credit: Sara Farid for The New York Times
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s fall may hold broader dangers at a time when he has set himself up as the opponent to the forces of nativism tearing at the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: With Vatican Talks and Bulldozers, China Aims to Control Christianity
item.media:description: A Palm Sunday procession toward a government-approved church in a village in Hebei Province in March.
item.description: The moves to assert control over Catholic and Protestant churches reflect a broader effort to establish control over society under President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Fears of Maldives Crisis Ease After President Concedes Election Loss
item.media:description: The opposition presidential candidate Ibrahim Mohamed Solih, center, with his running mate, Faisal Naseem, right, at a rally in Malé, Maldives, on Monday.
item.description: Official results give a decisive victory to the opposition candidate, Ibrahim Mohamed Solih, who promised to restore democratic freedoms and warmer ties with India.
item.dc:creator: HASSAN MOOSA and MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: It’s ‘One Tough Year’ After Hurricanes Tore Through British Virgin Islands
item.media:description: Two workers repair the roof of a house in Round Hill, Tortola.
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
item.description: While much attention has focused on Puerto Rico’s slow recovery from Hurricanes Maria and Irma, other islands have also struggled. The British Virgin Islands were among the worst hit.
item.dc:creator: LUIS FERRÉ-SADURNÍ

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, at Labour Party Conference, Faces Pressure on New Brexit Vote
item.media:description: Anti-Brexit demonstrators on Sunday outside the conference center in Liverpool, England, where the opposition Labour Party is holding its annual conference.
item.description: The leader of the British opposition party hopes that the Brexit crisis will prompt a general election. But many Labour supporters want another referendum, and he says he will listen.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: China Dispatch: Welcome to College. Your Parents Are in the Tents Next Door.
item.media:description: Parents of first-year students camping at Tianjin University as their children settle in for their new life.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Parents of first-year college students in China live in tents on campus to make goodbyes easier. Critics say they are pampering a generation of only children.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Hong Kong Bans Pro-Independence Party
item.media:description: Andy Chan, founder of the Hong Kong National Party, leaving the Foreign Correspondents' Club in Hong Kong in August.
item.description: The small party, with a handful of members and no elected lawmakers, had attracted government scrutiny for its call for Hong Kong independence from China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The

item.title: Iran’s President Condemns Gulf State, and U.S., After Deadly Attack
item.media:description: The aftermath of the attack at a military parade in Ahvaz, Iran, on Saturday that left dozens dead.
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani said that a Persian Gulf country allied with the United States was behind the strike against a military parade, that killed 25 people and wounded nearly 70 others.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Giving Malaria a Deadline
item.media:description: A false-color scanning electron micrograph of an Anopheles gambiae mosquito. By using a method called a gene drive, researchers believe they can eliminate a population of disease-carrying mosquitos within a dozen generations.
item.description: With a new genetic tool, scientists move a step closer to eradicating mosquitoes and the deadly diseases they carry.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs May Hurt, but Quitting China Is Hard to Do
item.media:description: Garment workers earlier this month arriving for their shifts at a factory in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Companies are reconsidering where to put their factories as the trade war mounts, but few places can match China’s convenience and reliability.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Iran’s Revolutionary Guards, Humiliated by Attack, Vow to Retaliate
item.media:description: A funeral ceremony in Ahvaz, Iran, on Monday for the victims of the attack on a military parade.
item.description: As its neighbors refuse to condemn an attack on a military parade that killed 25, the country said it would strike back against what it sees as a campaign to undermine its government.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Charles Kao, Nobel Laureate Who Revolutionized Fiber Optics, Dies at 84
item.media:description: Charles Kuen Kao doing an early experiment on optical fiber at the Standard Telecommunications Laboratory in Harlow, England, in the 1960s. He shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2009.
item.media:credit: Chinese University of Hong Kong, via EPA
item.description: In the 1960s, Dr. Kao outlined the potential capacity of fiber optic cables for storing information, laying the technical groundwork for modern communications.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The

item.title: App-Only Banks Rise in Europe and Aim at Traditional Lenders
item.media:description: Tom Blomfield, a founder and the chief executive of Monzo, a banking start-up in Britain. “The internet lets you run these traditional businesses at a fraction of the cost,” he said.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Favorable regulations and an influx of venture capital have made London a testing ground for banks without physical branches.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: German Government Reaches Deal in Spy Chief Dispute
item.media:description: Hans-Georg Maassen, left, and Germany’s interior minister, Horst Seehofer.
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s governing coalition resolved a standoff over the intelligence chief, who was accused of being too sympathetic to the far right.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pope Francis Warns of Anti-Semitism and Revisionism on Baltics Trip
item.media:description: Pope Francis in Kaunas, Lithuania, on Sunday.
item.description: The pontiff marked the annual remembrance for Lithuania’s Jewish community that was nearly wiped out during World War II. He also paid his respects to Lithuanians deported to Siberian gulags.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Maldives Opposition Declares Election Victory
item.media:description: Maldivians lined up in Malé, the capital, on Sunday to vote in the presidential election.
item.description: Local news organizations said Ibrahim Mohamed Solih had won decisively, but Abdulla Yameen, the autocratic president, had yet to concede.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and HASSAN MOOSA

item.title: Hong Kong Is Bound Tighter to China (by Bridge and Bullet Train)
item.media:description: On Sunday, Hong Kong gets a high-speed rail connection to Guangzhou and other cities in mainland China. Not everyone is thrilled.
item.description: Multibillion-dollar projects will speed connections between the former British colony and mainland China. Some think they have more to do with politics than economic concerns.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Wildfire Breaks Out Near Crowded Refugee Camp on Greek Island
item.media:description: The Moria migrant camp and the adjacent, makeshift settlement earlier this week.
item.description: It was the latest challenge to the health and safety of thousands of refugees living in squalor on the island of Lesbos.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Survivor Found in Tanzania Ferry, Days After Deadly Capsizing
item.media:description: Tanzanian divers stood on the MV Nyerere as they searched for bodies in Lake Victoria on Saturday.
item.description: Divers rescued the man on Lake Victoria on Saturday, two days after the MV Nyerere overturned, killing at least 209 people.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Gunmen Strike at Military Parade in Iran
item.description: The attack came in Ahvaz, a center of antigovernment protests.

item.title: Quebec Election Looms but a Traditional Issue Doesn’t: Independence
item.media:description: The drive for independence has been subdued by Quebec’s relatively resilient economy. Unemployment is less than 6 percent.
item.description: As Quebecers go to the polls on Oct. 1 in provincial elections, the issue of independence has been sidelined for the first time in decades.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Nicaraguan Migrants Fleeing Turmoil Test Costa Rica’s Good Will
item.media:description: A group of people illegally crossed the border between Nicaragua and Costa Rica this month, walking through a rice field in an area of Costa Rica called El Delirio, in Alajuela Province.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: Tens of thousands are seeking asylum, shelter and work, posing a challenge to the government and society of Nicaragua’s neighbor to the south.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: China and Vatican Reach Deal on Appointment of Bishops
item.media:description: Preparations before a Mass in Anyang, in the province of Henan, China, last month.
item.description: For the first time, the pope accepted the legitimacy of bishops chosen by the Communist Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Attack on Military Parade in Iran Kills at Least 25
item.media:description: Wounded soldiers at the scene of the attack. Officials blamed Arab separatists and the United States.
item.description: Some officials blamed Arab separatists, while others blamed the United States and Persian Gulf states for the assault.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Nigerian Herders Face Threat From Farmers Competing for Land
item.media:description: Cows heading to market in Gombe State, Nigeria, can fetch as much as $600 a piece.
item.media:credit: Adriane Ohanesian for The New York Times
item.description: Conflicts between farmers and herdsmen vying for land, which mirror the 20th-century range wars in the American West, are turning more violent.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: News Analysis: Is the World Becoming a Jungle Again? Should Americans Care?
item.media:description: President Trump at the NATO summit in Brussels in July. Mr. Trump’s apparent determination to upend traditional American diplomacy has set off debate about what the United States’ role in the world should be.
item.description: As President Trump upends decades of established foreign policy, thinkers on both sides of the Atlantic are grappling with questions about the United States’ role in the world.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Medellín Dispatch: 25 Years After Escobar’s Death, Medellín Struggles to Demolish a Legend
item.media:description: Tourists hiking past a prison guard tower, along the same path that Pablo Escobar used in 1992 to escape from the prison La Catedral.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: If the Colombian city cannot bury the memory of the drug lord Pablo Escobar, it at least wants to control how and where his story gets told.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Japan Has Enough Nuclear Material to Build an Arsenal. Its Plan: Recycle.
item.media:description: After decades of delays, a plant in Rokkasho, Japan, is almost ready to start turning nuclear waste into nuclear fuel, its builders say. But Japan doesn’t use much nuclear power any more.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Japan has spent decades building a facility to turn nuclear waste into nuclear fuel, but neighbors fear it has other plans for its plutonium.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
